race.name: Nanaimo Unpaved
race.tagline: Vancouver Island coastal forest gravel and mountain terrain near Nanaimo, BC.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through BC coastal countryside. Moderate elevation with coastal scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local BC event. Coastal terrain with moderate access, moderate costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Nanaimo Unpaved is a local event in BC—coastal terrain with moderate elevation. The BC coastal scenery is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local BC coastal gravel race. Worth it for BC/Canadian riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to BC—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better BC races: Kettle Mettle, TransRockies Gravel Royale.

logistics.food: Nanaimo has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: BC coastal weather is variable with rain possible.
BC coastal terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Pre-race check-in runs Saturday 10 AM-5:30 PM at Arrowsmith Bikes in town, then race day pickup 7:30-9 AM at Nanaimo MX Association track on Weigles Road. Getting to Vancouver Island still requires ferry planning or island flights, but the motocross venue provides established parking and facilities.

length.explanation: The 50-mile distance aligns with the Intermedio option (~85km), sitting between the 40km Impulso that Justin Filuk won in 2:13:10 and the 110km Esperto that took Fabian Merino 3:59:20. It's the middle ground that avoids both quick morning efforts and all-day epics. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: The course runs on Mosaic Forest Management's private gravel roads, accessing terrain normally closed to the public, plus incorporates sections of the Nanaimo Motocross Association track. Two DNFs out of 32 starters in the 2025 Impulso suggests manageable but selective technical demands. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 3,500 feet over 50 miles averages 70 feet per mile of climbing - steady undulation rather than defining ascents. The private Mosaic Forest Management roads likely provide consistent grades through managed timber terrain, but without major summit objectives. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: June 15 timing hits Vancouver Island's pre-summer sweet spot, and the low DNF rate (2 out of 32 riders in 2025) suggests conditions were manageable. The motocross venue provides some weather shelter, but coastal conditions remain unpredictable. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: This is Vancouver Island coastal terrain starting near sea level. No altitude considerations whatsoever - you're racing in coastal forest management roads that barely register elevation above the Strait of Georgia. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Vancouver Island offers adventure potential with its coastal terrain and forest roads, but this event provides zero specifics about what you'll actually encounter. The Trek series positioning as 'world's best gravel destination' is marketing hyperbole without course details to back it up. Real adventure requires unknowns, but these are the wrong kind of unknowns.

prestige.explanation: This is the finale event of a 3-race Vancouver Island series that includes Campbell River and Duncan, with Trek backing and local sponsors. Winners like Justin Filuk and Fabian Merino indicate regional competitive depth, but it's not drawing international attention.

race_quality.explanation: The 2025 edition drew 129 riders across three distances with proper wave starts, rider briefings, and professional photography by Jay Wallace. Post-race food trucks run 11 AM-3 PM with awards at 3 PM, showing solid event execution within the Trek BC Gravel Series framework.

experience.explanation: The motocross venue provides a distinctive racing atmosphere, and the private forest roads offer exclusive terrain access. Food trucks and drinks create a 4-hour post-race festival window, while the series finale positioning adds ceremonial weight to the day.

community.explanation: Strong masters participation includes competitive 65+ riders like 68-year-old Barbara Morris placing 5th overall in her category. The series draws families - 13-year-old Tessa Thibault and 15-year-old Tycho Thibault both completed the 40km distance, indicating multi-generational appeal.

field_depth.explanation: 129 total riders across three distances shows healthy participation, but the winning margins are significant - Mark Wiebe finished just 56 seconds behind Justin Filuk, while third place Carl Foght was over 5 minutes back. Regional depth without traveling competitive talent. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Registration fees aren't listed, but camping is included and it's part of a series with Trek backing, suggesting reasonable pricing. Three distance options mean you're not overpaying for more race than you need. Vancouver Island location delivers scenery and terrain value, and new events typically underprice to build their field.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $75-100 CAD. Vancouver Island access requires ferry costs from mainland BC or island flights, plus Canadian pricing throughout. The established motocross venue keeps logistics straightforward, and Nanaimo offers more lodging options than smaller island communities. Higher total cost than Badlands.

key_takeaways: Race history (founded year, founder if known): Inaugural events in the series context from 2024; Nanaimo Unpaved referenced as part of 2025 expansion

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Nanaimo Unpaved 2025 Gravel Bike Race
videos.description:
Gravel bike race in Nanaimo, British Columbia, Canada. 

From the  organizer,  Panache Cycling:

The 2025 TREK BC Gravel Series presented by Bluebird Self Storage and hosted by Mosaic Forest Management, features 4 epic events on Vancouver Island that take participants to the most challenging yet beautiful gravel routes of Vancouver Island.

This was one of them!

videos.title: 2024 Nanaimo Unpaved p/b Liquor Plus
videos.description:
The @trekbikes  Gravel Series on Vancouver Island presented by Mosaic Forest Management features 3 exciting and challenging events in Campbell River, Duncan, and Nanaimo.   

April 21 - River City Gravel Fondo p/b Riverway Dental
May 18/19 - Burnt Bridge Classic p/b Liquor Plus
June 16 - Nanaimo Unpaved p/b Liquor Plus

The event is also proudly supported by the  @DestinationCampbellRiver Nanaimo Hospitality Association  @myCVRD   @cowichantourism   @f2cnutrition781

videos.title: Nanaimo Unpaved Gravel Race| Impulso Distance | Highs and Lows Of Racing For Cookies
videos.description:
Come ride along with me as I ride the 'Impulso' (shorter) distance in the Nanaimo Unpaved Gravel race. I don't subscribe to Strava, so I was relying on the course markers. Even though the course was marked well, I questioned if I had made a wrong turn. This race is part of the Trek Gravel Series, hosted by Panache Cycling on Mosaic's forestry roads. This race had three distances, and the largest was the 'Esperto' route at 110 km and 2084 m of elevation. Feedback on this route was that it was the hardest gravel fondo for many. The other distance was the 'Intermedio' at 67 km with 1079 m of elevation and the shorter 'Impulso' route, which I rode, at 42 km with 890 m of elevation. I enjoy participating in races, even though they are very challenging for me. I try to encourage others to take part just for fun, for a challenge, and to enjoy the experience . As I mentioned many times in the video, I ride for cookies! 
#vancouverisland #gravelbiking #gravelracing #fitnesslifestyle #gravelcycling #cyclingrace #canadalife #specializedbikes #bicycle

videos.title: 2024 Burnt Bridge Classic pb Liquor Plus.   Event #3 of the Trek Gravel Series on Vancouver Island
videos.description:
@trekbikes Gravel Series on Vancouver Island presented by Mosaic Forest Management features 3 exciting and challenging events in Campbell River, Duncan, and Nanaimo.   

April 21 - River City Gravel Fondo p/b Riverway Dental
May 18/19 - Burnt Bridge Classic p/b Liquor Plus
June 16 - Nanaimo Unpaved p/b Liquor Plus

The event is also proudly supported by the @DestinationCampbellRiverr Nanaimo Hospitality Association @myCVRD @cowichantourism @f2cnutrition781@mosaicforests

quotes.text: We're here to have some fun behind Mountain Benson and riding the trails, the gravel roads, and it's my first gravel race. They changed the maps and they added 300 meters of climbing - wasn't that nice?

There is a creek crossing so you guys are going to be hanging a right and dropping down into a creek area. This is the quietest race I've ever been part of - there's no like 'wooo' or anything, everybody being quiet.
